item.title: If you're going to be kind to another human, today is the day to do it!
item.description: November 13 is World Kindness Day. Its goal is to encourage acts of kindness. (After all, one kind day is better than none.) Here's a look at the nature and nurturing of human kindness.

item.title: 'We need to get out of here': Trump's immigration crackdown is quietly reshaping where immigrants live in AmericaÂ
item.description: The Trump administration says that more than 1.6 million immigrants have self-deported. But there's also evidence of an internal migration from target cities and states and into quieter areas that feel safer.

item.title: Why home insurance is unaffordable, even in places without wildfires or hurricanes
item.description: Some of the country's highest home insurance prices are in the central U.S., a region generally considered to be protected from climate-driven disasters such as wildfires and hurricanes.

item.title: SNAP funding pause to soon end, but anxiety and anger may linger
item.description: The first ever disruption to the nation's largest anti-hunger program came as a shock. It's shaken trust in the program for some and stoked concern that it could happen again.

item.title: U.S. bishops officially ban gender-affirming care at Catholic hospitals
item.description: The bishops' decision formalizes a yearslong process for the U.S. church to address transgender health care. They also approved a special message on immigration, expressing concern over enforcement and conditions in detention centers.

item.title: Some Black police officials worry more federal agents will breed community mistrust
item.description: Missouri's governor recently authorized the state's National Guard to assist ICE with clerical duties. Black police officers fear the trust they've built with communities of color could take years to rebuild.
